text: What Trump did tonight is finally finish the rhetorical journey. He acknowledged what he's been the whole time: a nationalist, one of many in the world. He frames politics in transactional and deeply nationalistic terms, focused on perceived threats to his concept of the nation.
author: costareports

text: But it became clear over time that Trump's aversion to "nationalism" and "populism" wasn't an aversion to those *ideas* and what fueled them, but to the *people* associated w/ them. Identity-wise, he didn't want to be see as a Bannonite, a Buchananite, or part of a movement.
author: costareports

text: Trump used to wave me off in 2015-16 whenever I'd bring up the term "nationalism" or "populism." He hated them. Told me Trump the brand was bigger than those words and about "common sense." Never wanted to talk ideology... see this Aug. 2015 intvw, for ex.
author: costareports

text: The president's embrace of the word nationalism tonight is a marker, the culmination of many years of resisting the label, which he at first saw as a Bannon/Breitbart thing and a loaded, far right label that was an odd fit for a combative NY ex-Dem turned immigration hawk...
author: costareports

text:
The scene outside the Capitol right now: a swelling crowd of chanting protesters.

“No! No! No!”

Inside, in the marble halls, it’s quiet hours ahead of the vote. A few senators strolling around, their aides peering out the windows, stone-faced, as the cries grow louder.

text:
Sen. Collins: "Mr. President, I will vote to confirm Judge Kavanaugh. Thank you, Mr. President." 

Republicans applaud in the chamber.
author: costareports

text:
Here we go... Sen. Collins now turning to the allegations. 

"I cannot abandon them" she says about her beliefs in "presumption of innocence" and "fairness."

"We must always remember that is when passions are most inflamed, that fairness is most in jeopardy."
author: costareports

text: Unless this Collins speech takes a strong turn, some kind of M. Night-level twist, it's hard to see how she votes "no." Line after line is a defense of Kavanaugh's record.

text:
"Supreme Court justices have not hesitated to rule against the presidents who have nominated them," Sen. Collins says on the floor, as she explains her position on the Kavanaugh nom. She says Kavanaugh has clearly shown how "no president is above the law."

Supportive, so far.

text: Even w/ Murkowski on board with Flake, McConnell could still bring it to a floor vote. He has that option, could see how they react. But Mitch M. is not a big risk taker. The kind of guy who knows answers to every Q he asks. So, the vote looks to be delayed, pending probe.
author: costareports

text: The possible week delay adds the variable of the president's fury with Flake and the stalled process. Whatever Trump says/does could complicate the fragile whip count. “Somebody has got to explain this to Trump, I guess that will be my job!” Sen. Lindsey Graham told reporters.
author: costareports

text: Flake is a complicated figure. His friends say he's trying to protect GOP and the Court by making sure the FBI box is checked, and they think if Kavanaugh emerges fine from that, he may even win over some red state Ds.. but other Rs argue Flake knows he's all but dooming the nom
author: costareports

text: Now, McConnell has to figure out whether he can somehow get Collins and Murkowski to agree to a vote soon. But top sources say that's unlikely. So the next week becomes another pressure cooker as both sides debate/bicker over the scope over whatever steps are taken by the FBI.

Does the GOP have a Plan B in the works, should Kavanaugh withdraw?

He added, “Our Plan B is the same as our Plan A: Judge Kavanaugh.”

author: costareports

text: 4. Kavanaugh's most important ally right now is Don McGahn, the soon-to-be departing WH counsel who has made Kav's confirmation his personal legacy project/swan song, eager to score one last victory for the conservative legal estbmt. Huddled w/ the judge most of Monday...

text: 3. Don't underestimate the jockeying going on in GOP circles for a post-Kavanaugh world. Advocates for Hardiman, Coney Barrett, Thapar all talking w/ plugged-in friends in Congress or WH, ready for the possibility of further disruption of Kavanaugh nomination between now and Mon.
author: costareports

text: ... McConnell is the one who early on thought Judge Thapar would be best choice, but went along w/ WH. Now, as process cracks open, he's asserting himself even as he remains a team player. Allies tell me his priority is the SCOTUS seat, not protecting Kavanaugh every news cycle.
author: costareports

text: ... and there are ongoing debates internally over whether Dr. Ford wants to go through with it, whether Judge Kavanaugh can hold on, and whether the votes in Senate GOP can hold until then.   2. While the WH wants to drive the process, McConnell remains central to everything...

text: So, when Grassley and others express sadness, it's because a chaotic DC and a chaotic GOP are losing a conventional and trusty legal hand who helped keep Congress and WH united on at least one core issue, all while surviving Trump's moments of rage or pique. A rare skill.  /end
author: costareports

text: McGahn's goals and McConnell's goals and ideologies intertwined. Both wanted to get judges confirmed and feed Trump the successes he craves. And both wanted judicial confirmations to bolster their reps/legacies--McGahn's among DC lawyer community, McConnell for history books.
author: costareports

text: As McGahn's relationship with Trump has frayed, it has strengthened with GOP on Hill. They couldn't stand Bannon's theatrics and found others in WH tone deaf politically or disengaged. McGahn shared their conservative agenda, spoke their language. McConnell has kept him close.
author: costareports

text: The NYT story that highlighted McGahn's hours of interviews with Mueller was seen by McGahn and his friends as a problem--not the fact that he sat with Mueller, but how Trump would react. The headline is reality for POTUS. "Beginning of the end," as one McGahn ally put it to me.
author: costareports

text: McGahn takes immense pride on judicial work & has increasingly devoted his energies there + to lower profile reg work. Avoids Russia convos like the plague inside and outside WH. Has fully cooperated with Mueller but groused repeatedly about Cobb/Dowd decision to have him do so.
author: costareports

text: Flood is widely seen as likely replacement and was personally recruited by McGahn to join the WH back in the spring. Flood has built a rapport w/ POTUS, to McGahn's relief. But no decision finalized yet. Flood knows impeachment, shares McGahn worldview on exec priv.

text:
But the GOP is transformed. Ayers works for Trump. Bachmann is gone, but her right-wing immigration views (her best pal in House was Steve King) dominate the party. 

Pawlenty may feel burned tonight, but it's just a version of what he went thru in 2011. And the fire rages. /end
author: costareports

text: Pawlenty's comeback bid in MN was encouraged by GOP leaders and donors because it looked like not only a way to win the governor's mansion, but a way to reassure themselves that someone like him could still be a player. Mild-mannered, Sam's Club pitch but loved by C-Suite types.
author: costareports

text: What Trump saw, and Bachmann saw, and Santorum saw, to an extent, was that in the modern GOP, being a "Sam's Club Republican" is not enough. You cannot respond to economic anxieties with a policy program. Voters want visceral political campaigns, solidarity in grievance.
author: costareports

text: A few years later, sitting on a plane with Trump, I bring up Santorum and Pawlenty, and the flashes of populism in the party from 2012 cycle. Trump quickly dismisses the conversation and calls his brand of politics "common sense," not some ideological project.
author: costareports

text: Pawlenty, of course, goes on to drop out. Bachmann wins the Ames straw poll that summer but eventually fades. Months later, Rick Santorum, back from political winter, takes up many working-class talking points that are similar to T-Paw's and gives Romney a real race.
author: costareports

text: Pawlenty details his whole plan, his path to the nom. Sounds doable. Yet his delivery and his presentation are mild. It's the opposite style of Bachmann, who is roaring anti-establishment. And it's the opposite of a birtherism advocate from NYC making headlines at the time.
author: costareports

text: Pawlenty is confident but skittish about the rise of Bachmann. He's preaching his own version of populism (https://wapo.st/2PbrkdB ), "Sam's Club conservatism" that's embraced by Brooks and Salam and Douthat. He tells us that's the GOP future: winning over the working class.
author: costareports

text: A scene immediately comes to mind tonight as MN GOV primary results roll in, with Pawlenty finished. The scene: spring 2011. Pawlenty a GOP WH favorite. Nick Ayers, the wunderkind, on board. Donors mostly going to Romney, but many like TPaw. He meets with me and a few reporters.

Q: Has the president been speaking to Cohen recently?
A: “No. No. No. I don’t think so. I talk to Cohen’s lawyers, Jay talks to Cohen’s lawyers. But we try to make – both Jay and I know Cohen very well. And we both like him. He trusts us. So, no he hasn’t been talking to him"

text:
Q: So you won’t be fired for saying this?
A: “No! no! no! I’m not going to get fired (laughs). But if I do, I do. It wouldn’t be the first time it ever happened. But I don’t think so, no. (laughs)”
author: costareports

text:
Q: The president’s not angry with you? He was aware you’d bring it up?
A: “Oh, yeah, yeah. Sure, sure. He was well-aware that at some point when I saw the opportunity, I was going to get this over with.”
Q: You spoke about this w/ him in recent days?
A: “Probably 4 or 5 days ago"
